title: Doctor reveals why he turned down Caroline Flack’s reality show The Surjury
text:
A cosmetic doctor turned down Channel 4’s new show (Picture: Channel 4/Getty/Rex)

A cosmetic doctor has revealed why he turned down the chance to work on Caroline Flack‘s new controversial show The Surjury – as he warns it should never be someone else’s choice to go under the knife.

Love Island host Caroline, 39, was announced as presenter of the upcoming Channel 4 series, which will see people who want plastic surgery pitch their stories and requests to a jury made up of complete strangers.

The panel will then decide who will be granted their wish to have the procedure.

Earlier today Jameela Jamil shared an iNews article calling The Surjury ‘a new low for television’ and ‘dangerous and exploitative’ and tweeted: ‘Welp. Black Mirror is officially happening guys. It’s here.’

Dr Tijion Esho, cosmetic doctor and the founder of The ESHO Clinic, responded to the activist’s tweet voicing his disappointment that the show was still going ahead, despite turning it down months ago.

‘I got approached ages ago to do the show and I was pitched an idea from their team about what potentially the programme could be’, he explained to Metro.co.uk.

‘My initial understanding was that the people involved would be ones who were already thinking about getting surgery and then they would talk about why they wanted it done to a studio audience.’

The star is hoping to transform lives on the controversial series (Picture: ITV/REX)

However, when a press release was sent out, Dr Esho raised some concerns and realised it wouldn’t be ethical to take part.

He continued: ‘I tried to get more information about the show and in the end, I couldn’t get any more so it got to the point where I told my management that I couldn’t do it.

‘I had to look at it from an ethical point of view and to be responsible for the millennial generation.’

Dr Esho has raised concerns about the show (Picture: E4)

The 37-year-old who starred in E4’s Body Fixers revealed why having surgery was such a life-changing decision.

He said: ‘Having surgery is such a personal choice and it shouldn’t be based on a jury telling you whether or not to have something done.

‘The process of any procedure has big risks and to be honest I can’t think of any doctor who would take part so I am wondering who agreed to sign up to do it.’

Not only does cosmetic surgery have a physical impact on your body but Dr Esho said it also affects your mental health.

Dr Esho with the the Body Fixers crew (Picture: E4)

‘Any psychologist will tell you that anyone having surgery should do it for themselves and not because of the opinion of others, that should be separated and it goes against all of that.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘Body Fixers was a completely different show because it focused on helping people and we were allowed to know the whole format of the programme.

‘We featured people that had already had a botched treatment or something awful had happened to them, for example, we had someone who had suffered an acid attack and another that had botched lip fillers.

‘I enjoyed doing it because not only did we help them heal I was able to give people my help but on a larger platform.’

The Surjury is due to hit our screens in 2020 and Dr Esho hopes he is proven wrong.

He added: ‘I will be interested to see how the show turns out, and these kind of things attract people who are chasing surgery for the wrong reasons – and that are chasing some form of fame.

‘At the end of the day the treatment they will receive will be free so it gives people the incentive to apply. I did my own personal screening for patients in Body Fixers, and sometimes when you do treatments there can be complications afterwards, so who will be responsible for the aftercare?

‘I really hope that before I declined the show, that they took my advice and work alongside professional bodies as programmes like this have the potential to be good.’

Channel 4 defended the premise amidst the controversy, arguing: ‘Cosmetic surgery has become an increasingly mainstream choice in Britain. The Surjury seeks to explore why so many people feel the need to change their bodies, and whether surgery actually makes them happier.

Advertisement

‘All contributors featured in the series have actively been seeking surgery of their own accord. This new series allows them to consult with surgical teams and then to discuss their reasons for wanting it with a panel of their peers.

‘If their peers support their decision they will undergo the procedure of their choice subject to the usual surgical checks and consent processes. The show will neither glamorise nor condemn their choices: the aim is instead to interrogate the realities of cosmetic surgery.

‘Duty of care to contributors is of paramount importance and all will be independently assessed by the clinic who will carry out their procedure. They will be psychologically assessed and supported regarding their involvement in the programme.’

Caroline Flack has also defended the show by tweeted that the people who have taken part in the show have ‘been through a lot’

She tweeted: ‘I’ve filmed it and the people who have taken part are amazing and have been through a lot and life is about individual choice …’

A Channel 4 representative has been approached for a comment

The Surjury airs in 2020 on Channel 4.
